pullRequest.body:
Define equidecomposition and provide some basic theory and operations.

[Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Banach.20Tarski.20Paradox.20in.20Lean)

---

TODO:

Prove that if two sets embeddidecompose into eachother, they are equidecomposable (Schroeder-Bernstein type theorem)
Define embeddidecomposability as a Preorder on sets and prove that its induced equivalence relation is equidecomposability.
Prove the definition of equidecomposition used here is equivalent to the more familiar one using partitions. This equivalence is trivial mathematically, but partitions do not seem well-developed to me in mathlib.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...


Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Sorry for the secondary review - just noticed this after a second read.

Thanks!

maintainer delegate

add todo list

```suggestion

## TODO

* Prove that if two sets embeddidecompose into eachother, they are equidecomposable (Schroeder-Bernstein type theorem)
* Define embeddidecomposability as a Preorder on sets and prove that its induced equivalence relation is equidecomposability.
* Prove the definition of equidecomposition used here is equivalent to the more familiar one using partitions.

```

```suggestion
  ext <;> try rfl  
  rw [reflSet_source, ofSet_source]  
```

this should be private since it's specifically used to define Equidecomp and is otherwise not useful on its own.

(if it does get useful later, it's an easier transition from private to public than vice versa).

Hmm ok. Is it still OK that `DecompOn` appears in the definition of `Equidecomp`, though? Or should the definition of `Equidecomp` be changed to use the unfolded form of `DecompOn`, and `DecompOn` be used only internally to this file?
If it does stay in the definition, I suppose I should instead provide alternate constructors and elminators (?) for `Equidecomp` using the unfolded version?

> Hmm ok. Is it still OK that `DecompOn` appears in the definition of `Equidecomp`, though? Or should the definition of `Equidecomp` be changed to use the unfolded form of `DecompOn`, and `DecompOn` be used only internally to this file?

That's fine-ish. The first example of a `private def` auxiliary definition that I can think of is [equivPairAux](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/c98afaa5ebd20a5a656c38656f95ad1503d73194/Mathlib/GroupTheory/CoprodI.lean#L422-L431), which is used directly in the definition of `equivPair`.

> If it does stay in the definition, I suppose I should instead provide alternate constructors and eliminators (?) for `Equidecomp` using the unfolded version?

 Yes - though looking more at `Equidecomp`, `DecompOn` is the most direct way to construct `Equidecomp`, and I'm seeing some motivation to keep this public. Since I'm conflicted about this, I'll wait until a more established reviewer gives an opinion.
`DecompOn` should not be private if it is mentioned in public-facing API like `Equidecomp.decomp`.
Let me keep in public for now

```suggestion
def DecompOn (f : X â†’ X) (A : Set X) (S : Finset G) : Prop := âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ g âˆˆ S, f a = g â€¢ a
```

Since it has been decided, you can drop the private comment.

```suggestion
variable [SMul G X]

/-- Let `G` act on a space `X` and `A : Set X`. We say `f : X â†’ X` is a `DecompOn` `A`
```

```suggestion
theorem source_restr_subset_source (s : Set Î±) : (e.restr s).source âŠ† e.source := inter_subset_left
```

```suggestion
An *Equidecomposition* of `A` and `B` is typically defined as a finite partition of `A` together
with a finite list of elements of `G` of the same size such that applying each element to the
matching piece of the partition yields a partition of `B`.

This yields a bijection `f : A â‰ƒ B` where, given `a : A`, `f a = Î³ â€¢ a` for `Î³ : G` the group
element for `a`'s piece of the partition. Reversing this is easy, and so we get an equivalent
(up to the choice of group elements) definition: an *Equidecomposition* of `A` and `B` is a
bijection `f : A â‰ƒ B` such that for some `S : Finset G`, `f a âˆˆ S â€¢ a` for all `a`.

We take this as our definition as it is easier to work with. It is implemented as an element
`PartialEquiv X X` with source `A` and target `B`.
```

```suggestion
/-- Let `G` act on a space `X` and `A : Set X`. We say `f : X â†’ X` is a decomposition on `A`
```
so that people know how to pronounce it in speech

```suggestion
def IsDecompOn (f : X â†’ X) (A : Set X) (S : Finset G) : Prop := âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ g âˆˆ S, f a = g â€¢ a
```
since it's a prop but sounds like data
Can this be made a public lemma `toPartialEquiv_injective : Injective toPartialEquiv`?
done

```suggestion
/-- The restriction of an equidecomposition as an equidecomposition. -/
```

```suggestion
@[simps]
def restr (f : Equidecomp X G) (A : Set X) : Equidecomp X G where
```
should hopefully spare you a few lemmas below
Do you really need this definition? I would think using `(refl X G).restr A` is clearer
agreed

```suggestion
/-- The composition of two equidecompositions as an equidecomposition. -/
```
same below

```suggestion
```

Potential golf, but I'm unsure if this fits with the style guidelines (@YaelDillies?) - I wouldn't recommend committing it until this gets a second opinion.

```suggestion
theorem toPartialEquiv_injective : Injective <| toPartialEquiv (X := X) (G := G) := by
  intro âŸ¨_, _, _âŸ© _ _
  congr
```
Definitely fits, yes!

Golf that makes the proof clearer (and moves the implicit `_` variable to directly use the already introduced `a`)

```suggestion
theorem IsDecompOn.mono {f f' : X â†’ X} {A A' : Set X} {S : Finset G} (h : IsDecompOn f A S)
    (hA' : A' âŠ† A) (hf' : EqOn f f' A') : IsDecompOn f' A' S := by
  intro a ha
  rw [â† hf' ha]
  exact h a (hA' ha)
```

Unless you used an implicit binder here on purpose, it makes the definition more confusing.

```suggestion
    f.decomp.mono (source_restr_subset_source _ _) fun _ â†¦ congrFun rflâŸ©
```

```suggestion
An *equidecomposition* of `A` and `B` is typically defined as a finite partition of `A` together
```

```suggestion
* Define embeddidecomposability as a preorder on sets and prove that its induced equivalence
```

```suggestion
theorem apply_mem_target {f : Equidecomp X G} {x : X} (h : x âˆˆ f.source) :
    f x âˆˆ f.target := f.toPartialEquiv.map_source h
```
I don't really understand this name. Can you explain?
This should also have an explicit return type.
I think I struggled on choosing this. I was thinking "these are the group *elements* by which the pieces in the equidecomposition move". If you would suggest another name please let me know

Not much comes to mind either, possibly `witness` or `witnessSet` which is better than `elements` but still quite bad. I guess pick your favorite name out of those suggestions and leave a TODO to improve the name

```suggestion
theorem source_restr (f : Equidecomp X G) {A : Set X} (hA : A âŠ† f.source) :
```

```suggestion
theorem toPartialEquiv_restr (f : Equidecomp X G) (A : Set X) :
```

```suggestion
theorem restr_of_source_subset {f : Equidecomp X G} {A : Set X} (hA : f.source âŠ† A) :
```

```suggestion
  toPartialEquiv := .refl _
```

```suggestion
@[simps]
def refl : Equidecomp X G where
```
similarly, should this be `simps toPartialEquiv`

```suggestion
theorem refl_toPartialEquiv : (Equidecomp.refl X G).toPartialEquiv = .refl X := rfl
```

```suggestion
@[simps, trans]
noncomputable def trans (f g : Equidecomp X G) : Equidecomp X G where
```
Should I use `simps toPartialEquiv` ?
Whichever works and is useful!

```suggestion
/-- The inverse function of an equidecomposition as an equidecomposition. -/
```

```suggestion
theorem invFun_eq_symm (f : Equidecomp X G) : f.invFun = f.symm := rfl
```

```suggestion
@[symm, simps toPartialEquiv]
```

```suggestion
theorem isDecompOn_source_withness (f : Equidecomp X G) : IsDecompOn f f.source f.witness :=
  f.decomp'.choose_spec
```
I think it is worth keeping this name short since it is the key property of an equidecomposition and will be invoked repeatedly when working with them. I like `Equidecomp.isDecompOn`
This word "embeddidecompose"  only occurs in the module docstring. And I don't know what it means. Is this common terminology in the literature?

Ooops, that's from an older version. I will rewrite it, thanks. 

(It's not standard terminology, but I've heard people use "embeddidecomp" for "equidecomposition with a subset")

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Algebra/Group/Action): add definition of equidecomposition
